title: Chips
description: Chips help people enter information, make selections, filter content, or trigger actions.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Chips can show multiple interactive elements together in the same area, such as a list of selectable movie times, or a series of email contacts. There are four types of chips: assist, filter, input, and suggestion.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Assist chip
2. Filter chip
3. Input chip
4. Suggestion chip

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)
Available
M2 guideline â€“ ChipsAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterAvailable
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Chips represent options in a specific context, unlike buttons, which are persistent
  • There are four kinds of chips: Assist, filter, input, and suggestion
  • While the default elevation is 0, chips can be elevated if the placement requires protection, such as on top of an image
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color
  • Shape: Rounded rectangle
  • Types: Action chips have been separated into assist chips and suggestion chips. Choice chips are now a subset of filter chips.

contentChunks.footer: Chips have rounded rectangle shapes and updated color mappings.
contentChunks.altText: Assist and filter chips in M3 style

contentChunks.footer: M2: Types of chips are input, choice, filter, and action chips.
contentChunks.altText: M2 chip types

contentChunks.footer: M3: Types of chips updated to assist, filter, input, and suggestion chips.
contentChunks.altText: M3 chip types

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Contents

Assist chip
Filter chip
Input chip
Suggestion chip

This section contains component attributes, token mappings, and default values for quick reference or building your own design files and implementations.

Assist chip color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

contentChunks.footer: Chips
contentChunks.altText: 4 types of chips: Assist, filter, input, and suggestion

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Chips allow users to enter information, make selections, filter content, or trigger actions. While buttons are expected to appear consistently and with familiar calls to action, chips should appear dynamically as a group of multiple interactive elements.

contentChunks.footer: Chips appear as a group of interactive elements.
contentChunks.altText: 3 assist chips in restaurant review app

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Chips arenâ€™t buttons

Chips and buttons are similar in that they both provide visual cues to prompt users to take actions and make selections. However, there are important distinctions to be aware of.

Multiple chips should appear together in a group, whereas there should be no more than 3 buttons in a single arrangement.

contentChunks.footer: Donâ€™t use a chip in place of a button. Static actions that move the user forward or backward in the flow, like Save or Cancel, should be displayed as buttons.
contentChunks.altText: Chips used for Save and Cancel actions in a dialog

contentChunks.footer: Do use chips to present contextual, supplemental options.
contentChunks.altText: Chips used for â€œReserve a tableâ€ and â€œOrder deliveryâ€ in a restaurant app

contentChunks.htmlValue: Chips are reactive and contextual, whereas buttons are static and predetermined. A chip should offer a different action depending on the nature of the content it supports, whereas a button should be a persistent fixture of a layout. From a user-flow perspective, chips represent forking paths in an experience while a button represents a linear step along a flow.

contentChunks.footer: Don't use chips for flow-ending actions.
contentChunks.altText: Chip labeled â€œSave taskâ€ in a task management app

contentChunks.footer: Do use buttons for flow-ending actions.
contentChunks.altText: Button labeled â€œSave taskâ€ in a task management app

contentChunks.htmlValue: Chips should always appear in a set. Chip sets can be scrolled horizontally.

contentChunks.footer: Donâ€™t display a single chip by itself. Chips should appear in a set.
contentChunks.altText: Single chip in event reminder

contentChunks.footer: Chips can be scrolled horizontally.
contentChunks.altText: Multiple chips in event reminder

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Types

There are 4 types of chips:

  1. Assist chip
  2. Filter chip
  3. Input chip
  4. Suggestion chip

Choose the type of chip based on its purpose and author. Does the chip represent an action, communicate information, or filter results? Is its content generated by the product? Is it generated by the person using the product?

contentChunks.footer: 1. Assist  2. Filter  3. Input  4. Suggestion
contentChunks.altText: 4 chip types

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Purpose, authorChip typeRationaleExample

Action, product-authored

Assist chip

Assist chips represent smart or automated actions that can span multiple apps.

â€œAdd to calendarâ€ action

Filter, product-authored

Filter chip

Filter chips represent filters for a collection.

Platform selector on material.io/components

Information, user-authored

Input chip

Input chips represent discrete pieces of information entered by a user.

Gmail contact in the â€œToâ€ field

Information, product-authored

Suggestion chip

Suggestion chips help narrow a userâ€™s intent by presenting dynamically generated suggestions.

Suggested chat response
Anatomy

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
2. Label text
3. Leading icon or image (optional)
4. Trailing remove icon (optional, input & filter chips only)
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of 4 elements of a chip

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

All chips are slightly rounded with an 8dp corner.

contentChunks.footer: Chips have rounded corners.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of rounded corner of chip container

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Shadows and elevation

Chip containers can be elevated if the placement requires protection, such as on top of an image.

contentChunks.footer: If a chip needs visual protection, its container can be elevated.
contentChunks.altText: 3 elevated assist chips above image of Mount Rushmore

contentChunks.footer: Instead of elevation, chips can use an outline to define their container edge.
contentChunks.altText: 3 types of chips in an outlined style

contentChunks.footer: Chips may use elevation when placed on an image.
contentChunks.altText: 4 types of chips in an elevated style above restaurant photograph

contentChunks.footer: Donâ€™t elevate resting state chips unless they are placed over content requiring separation.
contentChunks.altText: 4 elevated chips above blank background

contentChunks.footer: Donâ€™t elevate chips when pressed. Use the ripple to visually indicate interaction.
contentChunks.altText: Elevated chip in pressed state

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Label text

Chip label text should be 20 characters or fewer, and have the same typography style as buttons.


Input chipAssist chipSuggestion chipFilter chip
Button (for comparison)

Word choice

User-generated

Begins with a verb unless the verb is â€œseeâ€ or â€œviewâ€

Noun / Category

Noun / Category

Verb

Example 1

username@gmail.com

Open in Drive

Height

Height

Save

Example 2

Red

Menu

Dogs

Dogs

Checkout

Filter labels should describe the nature of a filter set, while remaining short and succinct for the limited space available. It's OK to skip conventional grammar rules, such as articles (take "a" walk), to save space.Â

contentChunks.footer: Keep chip labels short and clear.
contentChunks.altText: Filter chip in maps app labeled â€œWalkingâ€

contentChunks.footer: Donâ€™t use chip labels longer than 20 characters.
contentChunks.altText: Filter chip in maps app labeled â€œWalking navigation sessionâ€

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Leading icon or image (optional)

Chips can contain an icon, logo, or image in a circular crop to represent the entity entered by the user.

System icons can also be used as a leading thumbnail for chips, such as when signifying filtered types in a search query.

contentChunks.footer: Input chips can contain a circular-cropped icon, logo, or  image.
contentChunks.altText: 2 input chips, one with a leading circular avatar and the other with a leading icon

contentChunks.htmlValue: Leading icon color for unselected chips can be customized through theming. While the default color is primary, the on surface variant color is a good alternative for when the icon style requires less emphasis.

contentChunks.altText: 2 screens asking people to "Share your experience" at a restaurant by selecting selecting chips labeled "Add photos" or "Add dishes." The leading icons in one screen are green, and in the other are grey.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Leading images are sized larger than leading icons to provide more space for detail.Â 

Where icons are specifically designed to be legible at small sizes, images such as user-selected avatars often benefit from additional room.

See the Specs tab for precise measurement values.

contentChunks.footer: Leading images, such as avatars, are sized larger than leading icons or logos.
contentChunks.altText: 2 input chips, one with a leading avatar 24dps big and the other with a leading icon 18dps big

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Trailing remove icon (optional, input and filter chips only)

On desktop and tablet, input and filter chips may contain a trailing X icon to directly remove the chip.

contentChunks.footer: The X icon (A) should be vertically centered in the chip and placed within equal margins on either side (B).
contentChunks.altText: â€œXâ€ Close icon in chip

contentChunks.footer: Include the left and right margins (A) around the icon (B) to give the Close icon action a target size that is accessible on desktop and tablet.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of target size of â€œXâ€ Close icon in chip

contentChunks.htmlValue: Assist chips

Assist chips represent smart or automated actions that can span multiple apps, such as opening a calendar event from the home screen. Assist chips function as though the user asked an assistant to complete the action. They should appear dynamically and contextually in a UI.

An alternative to assist chips are buttons, which should appear persistently and consistently.

contentChunks.footer: The text in most assist chips begins with a short verb (like Get or Add).
contentChunks.altText: 2 assist chips labeled â€œAdd to my itineraryâ€ and â€œ12 mins from hotelâ€ on map screen about Los Cantantes

contentChunks.footer: An assist chip can surface supplemental information like a calendar event, as well as provide contextual actions.
contentChunks.altText: 2 assist chips labeled â€œEvent locationâ€ and â€œChatâ€ on phone lock screen

contentChunks.footer: During an interaction, assist chips can transform into modals, transition into full-screen views of new content, or readjust to display more results inline.
contentChunks.altText: Assist chip transformed into time picker with radio buttons

contentChunks.htmlValue: Assist chips can trigger an action or show progress and confirmation.

contentChunks.footer: Tapping an assist chip triggers a contextual action.
contentChunks.altText: 3 assist chips labeled â€œShare with So,â€ â€Read laterâ€ and â€œBookmarkâ€ on an article preview

contentChunks.footer: Assist chips can show progress and confirmation feedback.
contentChunks.altText: Assist chip showing confirmation upon selection

contentChunks.htmlValue: Assist chips are displayed after primary content, such as below a card or persistently at the bottom of a screen.

contentChunks.footer: Assist chips should be shown underneath primary content.
contentChunks.altText: 2 assist chips labeled â€œTurn on lightsâ€ and â€œSet alarmâ€ on Welcome Home screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Filter chips

Filter chips use tags or descriptive words to filter content. They can be a good alternative to toggle buttons or checkboxes.

Tapping on a filter chip activates it and appends a leading checkmark icon to the starting edge of the chip label.

contentChunks.footer: Filter chips rely on tags or descriptive words to filter content.
contentChunks.altText: 4 filter chips labeled â€œDocsâ€ â€œSlidesâ€ â€œSheetsâ€ and â€œImagesâ€ with â€œSlidesâ€ and â€œSheetsâ€ selected

contentChunks.footer: Filter chips in a shopping app
contentChunks.altText: 5 filter chips representing popular electronics categories in a shopping app. The chip â€œGame consolesâ€ is selected.

contentChunks.footer: Filter chips in a real estate app
contentChunks.altText: 6 filter chips representing apartment amenities in a real estate app. 2 of the chips are selected.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Tap a chip to select it. Multiple chips can be selected or unselected.

contentChunks.footer: An icon can be added to indicate when a filter chip is selected.
contentChunks.altText: 6 filter chips representing apartment amenities in a real estate app. 2 selected chips include checkmarks while 4 others do not

contentChunks.footer: Filter chip suggestions can dynamically change as users start to select filters.
contentChunks.altText: A filter chip is selected from a group of 6 chips. 3 of the chips disappear, changing

contentChunks.htmlValue: Alternatively, a single chip can be selected. This offers an alternative to toggle buttons, radio buttons, or single select menus.

contentChunks.footer: Filter chips can be set so that selecting a single chip automatically deselects all other chips in the set.
contentChunks.altText: 4 filter chips labeled â€œExtra softâ€ â€œSoftâ€ â€œMediumâ€ and â€œHardâ€ with the â€œMediumâ€chip selected

contentChunks.htmlValue: On desktop and tablet, filter chips may contain a trailing icon to directly remove the chip or open a menu of options.

contentChunks.footer: The X close icon indicates that a user can unselect the filter chip.
contentChunks.altText: Filter chip with trailing close icon

contentChunks.footer: A trailing menu icon indicates that a user can select the chip to see a list of filter options.
contentChunks.altText: Filter chip with trailing menu icon

contentChunks.htmlValue: When combined with a menu, the filter chip opens a list of selectable options.

contentChunks.footer: On mobile, use a trailing menu icon with caution as the target area is often too small for an accessible interaction.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Filter chips can be used with other components, such as search fields and sheets.

contentChunks.footer: Filter chips can be shown underneath a search field.
contentChunks.altText: 4 filter chips below search field

contentChunks.footer: Other components, such as search fields and sheets, can incorporate filter chips.
contentChunks.altText: Tags used as filter chips in a file application

contentChunks.footer: Filter chips can wrap to a new row. If there are more than 2 rows, consider using horizontal scrolling to access them all.
contentChunks.altText: 6 filter chips wrapping to 2 rows

contentChunks.footer: Filter chips can scroll horizontally to show unlimited options.
contentChunks.altText: 4 filter chips with right-most chip partly offscreen, indicating the chips are horizontally scrollable

contentChunks.footer: Filter chips should not present only a single option.
contentChunks.altText: Single filter chip option beneath the header â€œCategoryâ€

contentChunks.htmlValue: Input chips

Input chips represent discrete pieces of information entered by a user, such as Gmail contacts or filter options within a search field.

They enable user input and verify that input by converting text into chips.

contentChunks.footer: Input chips transform text based on user input.
contentChunks.altText: Contacts transformed into 2 input chips in a draft event invite

contentChunks.htmlValue: Input chips can support editing to change their contents, such as correcting an email address. In edit mode, the chip reverts back to a text string. Editing can be triggered by interacting with the chip, either by selecting it or by a second interaction after selection.

contentChunks.footer: Input chips converted from email addresses are editable.
contentChunks.altText: Contact transformed into input chip in the â€œToâ€ filed of an email draft

contentChunks.htmlValue: A single field can contain multiple input chips, and those chips can be reordered or moved into other fields.

contentChunks.footer: Multiple input chips in one field.
contentChunks.altText: 2 input chips in the â€œToâ€ field of an email draft

contentChunks.footer: Input chips being moved from one field to another.
contentChunks.altText: 1 input chip moved from the â€œToâ€ field to the â€œCCâ€ field of an email draft

contentChunks.htmlValue: Input chips can expand to show more information or options. A container transform transition pattern is used to reveal additional content.

contentChunks.footer: Input chips can expand.
contentChunks.altText: Contact input chip expanded to show multiple email addresses for that contact

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Placement

Input chips can be integrated with other components.

They can appear:

  • Inline with the text input cursor in a field
  • In a stacked list
  • In a list that can be horizontally scrolled

contentChunks.footer: Input chips can wrap to a new row if all chips need to be visible.
contentChunks.altText: 4 input chips wrapping to 2 rows

contentChunks.footer: Input chips that scroll horizontally.
contentChunks.altText: 3 input chips horizontally scrolling

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Icons and images

Input chips can contain an icon, logo, or image in a circular crop to represent the entity entered by the user.

System icons can also be used as a leading thumbnail for input chips, such as when signifying filtered types in a search query.

contentChunks.footer: Input chips can contain an icon, logo, or circular-cropped image.
contentChunks.altText: 2 input chips, 1 with leading thumbnail, 1 with leading icon

contentChunks.htmlValue:
On desktop and tablet, input chips may contain a trailing X icon to directly remove the chip.

Using this X is cautioned on mobile, as the target area is too small for accessibility.

  1. Close icon

  2. Interactive target, including 8dp of padding

contentChunks.footer: The X icon (A) should be vertically centered in the chip and placed within equal margins on either side (B).
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of chip indicating vertical icon alignment

contentChunks.footer: Include the left and right margins around the icon (A) to give the close action a target size (B) that is accessible on desktop and tablet.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of chip indicating size of interaction target for trailing icon

contentChunks.htmlValue: The trailing X is always aligned to the end side of the container. Itâ€™s placed on the right for left-to-right (LTR) languages, such as English, and on the left for right-to-left (RTL) languages, such as Farsi.

contentChunks.footer: Input chips with trailing Close icons
contentChunks.altText: 2 input chips with trailing icons following the label text

contentChunks.footer: Include the left and right margins around the icon to give the close action a target size that is accessible on desktop and tablet.
contentChunks.altText: 3 input chips with trailing icons following the label text

contentChunks.footer: Using the backspace key with the cursor before a chip selects the entire chip. The chip can then be deleted when the user taps the backspace key again.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram showing selection of chip with backspace key

contentChunks.footer: Overflowed chips in a text field should follow the same behavior as regular text. An unfocused text field with overflowed content should display the beginning of the input; tapping the field snaps the user to the end of the input with the cursor and keyboard active.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of overflowed chips in a text field

contentChunks.htmlValue: Suggestion chips
Suggestion chips help narrow a userâ€™s intent by presenting dynamically generated suggestions, such as possible responses or search filters.

contentChunks.footer: The text labels within suggestion chips are most often nouns or short phrases.
contentChunks.altText: 3 suggestion chips offering ID options in a photo-recognition app

contentChunks.footer: Suggestion chips can offer quick-reply options in a chat or email app.
contentChunks.altText: 3 suggestion chips with automated reply options in a chat app

contentChunks.footer: A suggestion chip can help the user start a search.
contentChunks.altText: 2 suggestion chips with search options â€œWhatâ€™s the weather today?â€ and â€œWhatâ€™s the news?â€

contentChunks.htmlValue: Placement

When displaying multiple chips together, place them inline as a row of options, not listed vertically. Overflowing chips should break to the next line (unless placed in a fixed-height field).

Keep an 8dp minimum space between chips. Chips must also have a minimum 48dp target size (regardless of placement or density). If required, the target can extend beyond the visible container of the chip.

Text labels for chips should be concise. However, chip labels will truncate when in a wrapped layout, and when they are wider than the full width of the screen.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Margins between chips
2. Margin between each line
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of margins between a set of chips

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Accessibility guidelines coming soon

In progress: complete guidance for accessible interaction, keyboard navigation, labeling, and more. Learn more about accessibility.
